Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the major intellectual achievements of the 20th century was the development of the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics. This model succeeded in classifying all of the elementary particles known at the time into a hierarchy of groups having similar quantum properties. The validity of this model to date was recently confirmed by the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at the CERN laboratory near Geneva, Switzerland. However, the Standard Model as it currently exists, leaves open many questions about the universe. These include why matter dominates over anti-matter in the Universe (CP violation), the values of the masses of the fundamental constituents of matter, the quarks and the leptons, the size of the mixings among the quarks, and separately among the leptons, and the properties of dark matter. Most explanations require the presence of new forces and the development of concepts that now constitute what we call physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM). This award supports research that addresses those questions that dominate BSM physics. The research will be carried out at the LHC, which is the premier High Energy Physics particle accelerator in the world and one of the foremost facilities for answering these BSM questions.

LHCb is the first experiment designed specifically to study the decays of hadrons containing b or c quarks at a hadron collider. The goal of LHCb is to identify new physics in nature by examining the properties of hadrons containing these quarks. New physics, or new forces, are manifest by particles, as yet to be discovered, which would modify decay rates and CP violating asymmetries, and thus allow new phenomena to be observed indirectly. In direct searches for new particles, the accelerator's energy must be high enough to allow the particle to be produced. In indirect searches effects of new particles can be seen even if they have a much higher mass than can be seen directly, because the effects are quantum in nature, and appear in Feynman diagrams where the particles are" virtual", so they are emitted and absorbed over short times.

LHCb has operated very successfully starting in late 2010. This award will allow the study of rare decays of heavy quark systems. These decays provide a unique window into physics at an energy scale well beyond that accessible by explicit production of new particles at colliders. This is increasingly important as the limits for new physics by CMS and ATLAS increase, the only window may turn out to be in the studies of rare decays. This work will concentrate mostly on charm quark physics, the expertise of the group. These charm channels can show BSM physics in CP violation and other parity violating asymmetries. Any discovery of BSM physics would be a huge step forward in our understanding of the fundamental physics of the universe. In addition, this award will facilitate a small part of the ongoing LHCb detector upgrade that will improve the overall ability of the detector to fully exploit the LHC data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to advance understanding of 'flavor physics', especially the physics of hadrons containing charm and/or bottom quarks. In conjunction with acquiring and analyzing data, the project supported efforts related to developing new types of analyses and preparing for the next generation of the LHCb experiment.


Secondary goals included educating graduate students, undergraduate students, high school students, and their physics teachers.


During the award period, personnel supported by this grant (especially post-docs Liang Sun and Simon Akar and Ph.D. student Adam Davis) were principal analysts/authors of three refereed journal papers reporting analyses of BaBar data [Phys. Rev. D93, 112014 (2016); Phys. Rev. D95, 052004 (2017); and PRL 119, 202003 (2017)] ,and two reporting analyses of LHCb data [Phys. Rev. D95, 052004 (2017) and JHEP 07, 021 (2017)]. The topics ranged from studies of particle-antiparticle oscillations in the neutral charm meson system to precise charm meson mass difference measurements to B-meson decay studies. Simon Akar was also a principal author of a phenomenology paper that has been submitted for publication [arXiv:1802.090433]. We were principal authors/analysts of additional physics studies reported at conferences and published in proceedings. In particular, Christoph Hasse, a visiting Masters student from TU Dortmund University, demonstrated the physics reach of a time-dependent amplitude analysis for studying particle-antiparticle oscillations in the neutral charm meson system using four-body final states [J.Phys.Conf.Ser. 898, no.7, 072016 (2017)] and Adam Davis, then a UC graduate student, developed a new method for studying lepton flavor universality in D meson decays and later presented it at an international conference [PoS CKM2016, 025 (2017)]. We also served as mentors to students from other institutions whose work we influenced significantly. UC personnel supported by related grants awarded to the PI were authors of six additional physics journal papers.


In terms of broader impact within LHCb, we helped build the intellectual infrastructure of the LHCb collaboration, a team of more than 800 physicists from about 80 institutions.  In particular, the PI served as the 'charm trigger coordinator' during the calendar year 2015 when he was a CERN Scientific Associate. In addition to helping other members of the Charm Physics Working Group write 'trigger lines' to select interactions for off-line analysis, he wrote about 100 himself and wrote the charged hyperon trigger lines, significantly extending the physics reach of the experiment. Simon Akar, one of our post-docs served as the Convener of the 'Flavor Tagging Working Group' for two years. To study oscillations of neutral B-mesons from particle to antiparticle, and vice versa, it is necessary to 'tag' whether each signal event was a particle or antiparticle at the time it is produced.  This work is critical to the experiment because studying asymmetries in the particle and antiparticle oscillation rates, and determining the parameters that govern these oscillations is, a key focus area for LHCb.  We also worked on developing the Upstream Tracker, a detector to be installed as part of the upgraded experiment for Run 3.


In terms of broader impact beyond LHCb,  we had a robust Education and Outreach program. We engaged three UC Ph.D. students, 10 UC undergraduates, 1 from another institution, and a Masters student from Dortmund in research. High school students and teachers also did research with us for six-week periods in the summers as part of our QuarkNet center activities. Students from several high schools came to UC each spring to participate in the International Particle Physics Outreach Group's Masterclasses.


Altogether, the support we enjoyed from this award allowed us to publish analyses of data from the BaBar experiment at SLAC and the LHCb experiment at CERN, to develop new ideas for future measurements, and to help prepare LHCb for taking data in Run 3, scheduled to start in 2021. It also provided opportunities for post-docs and students to enhance their knowledge of particle physics and develop research expertise. As is almost always true, we did not complete all the projects we had hoped to, but we made good progress trying.
